7.text:
Every aspect of our lives has been reshaped
by technology.

11.text: From the way we get around, the way we seek information, and the way we communicate.

16.text: It's easy to think that if only our technology advances enough, we'll finally be satisfied.

22.text: The fact is, we remain shackled by our primitive Darwinian brains.

37.text: Humanity, for whatever progress we have made,

39.text: is the result of an unguided, natural, 3.8 billion year long experiment

46.text: Evolution is the process that has made you what you are.

50.text: But it is not farseeing. It does not, and can not, consider the future,

56.text:
make decisions about where we ought to go,
how we ought to be.

60.text: Passing on genes is the only objective.

63.text: But as thinking human beings, we care about far more than that.

67.text:
Consciousness means that we have the capacity 
to experience the world,

72.text: to reflect upon, and - most importantly - to shape it.

78.text:
And so, what begins as Humanism - 
our most sympathetic understanding and treatment of human nature -

84.text:
becomes Transhumanism - the
drive to fundamentally revolutionise what

88.text:
it means to be human by way of
technological advancements.

93.text:
Changing human nature might be the most dangerous 
idea in all of human history,

103.text:
Generally speaking, Transhumanist thought
does two things:

107.text:
First, it considers current trends to see how future technologies will
develop, and how they might affect us.

114.text:
Second, it calls for the use of current, and upcoming
technology, to bring about beneficial societal change.

123.text: We'll examine three central areas of Transhumanist thought:

132.text:
dubbed "the three supers"
because of their extraordinary transformative potential.

137.text:
So let's begin with a thought experiment to
get your intuitions flowing:

141.text:
Consider this:
An evil organisation creates an airborne virus.

146.text: It infects you - and the entire human race.

150.text: As a result, 100,000 people are dying every day.

154.text:
Within thirty years, one in seven - a billion people - 
will have died because of the virus.

161.text:
Now, how much money should world leaders put into research 
to develop an antidote?

166.text: How high on a list of global priorities would you rate this?

170.text:
There is no denying the situation would be dire. 
Most people would demand immediate action.

177.text: But, hey, this is just a thought experiment, right?

181.text: 100,000 people really do die everyday from diseases caused by

189.text: But no-one treats ageing as a global priority...

192.text: So what explains this double standard?

194.text: Are we are simply resigned to death by ageing?

198.text:
Aubrey de Grey, an expert in research on ageing,
argues that our priorities are fundamentally skewed,

205.text:
and that we must start thinking seriously
about preventing the huge number of deaths due to ageing

210.text:
the greatest cause of fatal
diseases in the western world.

214.text: The goal of this strand of transhumanism is "superlongevity".

219.text:
Today, we have the minds and the equipment
to begin developing technologies to combat ageing.

224.text:
Unfortunately, we lack the will and
the financial support to do so.

229.text:
Most of us are so accustomed to the idea of growing old
that ageing seems like just a fact of life.

237.text:
If modern medicine is supposed to keep us
alive and healthy for as long as possible,

241.text:
then the anti-aging movement takes medicine
to its logical conclusion.

246.text:
It's what happens when "as long as possible" means 
"as long as we want".

252.text: But what would a world without ageing look like?

256.text: How would we manage the huge population growth?

260.text: And who would own the technologies that make it possible?

264.text: These are huge questions, but we only have time to raise them.

269.text: We'll investigate them in depth, in future videos.

272.text: Let's move onto the next area of transhumanist thinking:

278.text: Every year computers are getting more powerful.

280.text: What used to fill up a room now fits in our pockets.

283.text:
More crucially, the time it takes
for computer power to double is also getting shorter.

288.text: At the outset of computing, the doubling process took 18 months,

293.text: and this interval appears to be getting smaller.

296.text:
Plot this on a graph and it's not a straight line, 
but an exponential, upward curve.

302.text:
We need only project into the future to see
that there is a point at which this line is practically vertical:

308.text:
A moment in human history 
referred to as the technological singularity.

314.text:
The futurist thinker Ray Kurzweil postulates
that as these technologies develop,

318.text:
we will likely edit our bodies in order to integrate 
with computers more and more.

326.text:
We're already in a symbiotic
relationship with technology.

331.text:
You can send your thoughts at incredible speeds 
to recipients on the other side of the planet,

336.text: find your precise location using satellites,

339.text: and access the world's repository of recorded human knowledge

343.text: with a device you carry with you at all times.

346.text: And all of this was unthinkable 20 years ago.

350.text:
Out of this predicted computer capability
explosion, may eventually come

354.text: Artificial Intelligence; a simulated consciousness in silicon.

360.text:
Given the rate at which an AI will be able to improve itself, 
it will quickly become capable of thought with precision,

366.text: speed and intelligence presently inconceivable to the human mind.

371.text:
If Kurzweil is right, and we end up integrating ourselves 
with technology,

374.text: we could be in private contact with this AI whenever we choose.

380.text: The result of this is that we effectively merge with this AI, and its abilities become our own.

387.text: This would propel the human race into a period of super-intelligence.

392.text:
But, perhaps, as some argue, no non-biological
computer could ever become conscious.

399.text:
Or what if, as every other dystopian science fiction plot goes, 
this AI's goals differ from our own?

406.text:
And what does our increasing reliance
on computers mean for our future?

411.text:
Super-longevity and super-intelligence are
all well and good,

414.text: but only insofar as they make us happier, more fulfilled, more content.

420.text:
Let's look at the last section, which deals
with the issue of wellbeing.

424.text: Imagine you're soon to be a parent.

426.text:
Your doctor informs you that, if you wanted, 
you could choose certain features of your child's biology.

432.text: You could choose how genetically prone to depression they will be,

435.text: their levels of anxiety, jealousy, anger, and even their pain threshold.

442.text:
Would you choose a high likelihood of chronic
depression?

448.text: How about panic attacks and anxiety?

452.text:
The last major branch of Transhumanism, 
spearheaded by philosopher David Pearce,

457.text: aims to investigate and phase out suffering.

460.text:
He argues that ultimately, all our conscious
states - our feelings, mood, and emotions

467.text: - are all an expression of our brain chemistry.

470.text:
For Pearce, it is clear that natural selection
hasn't designed us to be happy;

475.text: it's designed us to be good at surviving and passing on genes.

478.text:
A species that is permanently anxious
and discontented will have a higher motivation

484.text: to watch out for predators, and take precautions for survival.

488.text: But in today's world, these emotions are vicious.

491.text: Our biology has barely changed in 200,000 years,

496.text:
which means that whilst culture and society 
has arguably made progress,

500.text:
we are still those same aggressive, jealous, anxious 
savannah-dwelling hunter-gatherers.

506.text: This is why Pearce argues that if we ever hope to increase the wellbeing of our species,

511.text: we will have to edit our genes.

515.text:
Minimizing our suffering - and the suffering
of those we care about - is a crucial part of what drives us.

522.text:
Hence, so called "abolitionists" argue that we start using 
modern technologies to do exactly that:

529.text:
minimize and eventually abolish suffering, 
ushering in an era of so-called superwellbeing.

536.text: At present, every child is a roll of the genetic dice.

540.text: Pearce argues that the least we can do is load the dice in our favour,

544.text: to create happier, healthier, longer-living humans.

549.text:
But might our compassion, curiosity, and pursuit
of knowledge become secondary to our hedonism?

556.text: If we're all content - why visit the stars?

558.text: And isn't suffering sometimes a good thing?

563.text:
These are three key areas of Transhumanist thought, 
and we've only begun to scratch the surface.

569.text:
The three supers: superlongevity,
superintelligence and superwellbeing,

576.text:
might radically change human history 
if - or when - they are realized.

581.text:
One of the main issues facing Transhumanist
ideals is that they are seen as far-fetched

587.text: or perceived as just science fiction.

589.text: But this is a big mistake.

604.text: We're in the process of redesigning what it is to be human,

608.text:
only the effects are still so subtle, and so slow, 
that it doesn't look like much.

614.text: But these changes will come faster and faster,

617.text:
and it's only wise to be an active,
informed participant in the next stage of human development.
